reviewText: I will start off by saying that this game has very little to actually do" in it
date: it is more of an interactive story almost
recommended: but not quite. The object of all three of the Sherlock Holmes Consulting Detective mysteries is to gather clues by deciding on what people and places to visit. Once you have gotten enough information to solve the crime/s you will go before a judge and he will ask a few questions that you must answer correctly.  Getting to the judge and answering questions using the fewest amount of clues that you can will give you a score. The goal is to solve the mystery by using only as many clues as it takes Holmes to solve the mystery. There is not a lot of replay ability in the game except if your score doesn't match Holmes' once you have solve the mystery.  I wouldn't expect it to take very many playthorughs to match Holmes scores.\n\nIf you like Sherlock Holmes
hoursPlayed: or some not too hard brain teasers
voteText: you will enjoy the game. It is only about 60-90 mins of total gameplay in most instances for each mystery. As for the price
helpfulPercent: I would definitely go the collection route as it's almost half price. I would probably also wait til it might be on sale as well."

reviewText: If you are a fan of Retro games, sure this is one to add to your library, don't expect something like Night Trap or Double Switch though.  I originally owned this game on Sega CD.  This game is short.  Given that it was originally bundled with 2 other cases when it first came out.  This game is alot better than I expected it to be given that I played the original version, either concerning video or the interface itself I came in expecting my experience on Sega CD and was suprised that it was better.  Hopefully they might release Volume II or III.  I did not hate the game and found it interesting. It's probably not for everybody and there are really better Sherlock games out there.  I bought it for Nostalgia purposes.  If you want to step into FMV history this is a good example of it.  Would I reccomend buying it? Yes.  But depending on what you want to buy it for.  I bought it for nostalgia purposes.  The game is decent, has it aged? Maybe a little....

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rrJUCwjLk5g

Sherlock Holmes Consulting Detective: The Case of the Mummy's Curse is for a certain type of video game fan. I can't claim to be one of them. Despite that I had a great time searching the newspaper for clues and watching the live action cut scenes. Something about this game's cheap production values wins me over, from  the amature acting to the obvious sets. Fans of this style of logical puzzle mystery will enjoy it a lot, even if I made the worst Sherlock Holmes in history.

PROS
-live action cutscenes
-simple UI

CONS
-plain presentation
-niche audience


DISCLAIMER: Review is based off approx. 1 hour of gameplay.

reviewText:
This was an enjoyable little game. Though it has little replay value, I quite liked it.
I must confess, I've become so used to games holding your hand that the lack of mandatory instruction was confusing at first. However, it was not a very difficult game to figure out.
You read the newspaper and watch live-action cutscenes of Sherlock interviewing suspects. Then you put the evidence together and present it to a judge.
It was less of a game, and more like an interactive episode of an older Sherlock show.
If you enjoyed Sherlock Holmes: Crime and Punishment, this game is similar to it.
Due to its lack of replay value, I would not advise spending over two dollars for this game.

reviewText:
5.0/10 - Very Short FMV detective game.

Honestly, the acting was bad. Sherlock and Watson were both uncharacteristic of anything I've seen. Didn't strike me as a super sleuth, the game was fun for 25 minutes.

You will scan newspapers for leads, check up on the leads and question characters via FMV. About 5-8 minutes of FMV per case completion. Extremely short and has little replay value but I still liked it.

Would have rated higher if they didn't try to call this Sherlock Holmes, and it wasn't so short.

Worth $0.50 max! Try to get all 3 cases for $0.99.

reviewText: This game is hard to review. Definitely kind of dull but not a bad game. I think the biggest tip you can get, is to talk to all of the Regulars, even if it doesn't seem like it would be helpful. One big annoyance is when using the Clue hints, they are in an automatic order so it often gave me hints about things I had already done, which is annoying because it damages your score to get those hints. I also never really found much of a use for using the Irregulars, aside from how it affects your score, as they always seem to get the exact same info you get by going there with the detectives, but when using the detectives you at least get to see the short videos. So in that way it becomes an enjoyment versus score debate and either way you essentially lose.\nBottom line: If you like this sort of game then, splurge. An hour of my time was worth the 0.82 cents for the game.

reviewText:
A running theme through this series is that the game system is excellent and the cases fail to live up to the possibilities. It's just as true with The Mummy's Curse, though it's at least the best of a bad lot.

The biggest problem with The Case of the Mummy's Curse is it becomes fairly obvious who your culprit is early on and there is one absolutely threadbare path that allows you to haul ♥♥♥ to the conclusion with irresponsible speed. But if you reach that conclusion like most people would, by checking with witnesses, contacts, investigative resources, etc., you could have a thorough, airtight case that still won't satisfy the judge. The game requires that you've done investigation X while investigation Y is intended to make it more clear if you're hesitant to make an accusation.

It's a mystery that lets you approach the mystery from a bunch of different angles to build your case but only respects one of those angles as the true way to resolve it. It's reminiscent of getting stuck in a Phoenix Wright game where you've already reasoned through much of the mystery but struggle with understanding the tiny logical steps the game excepts Phoenix to make in order to catch up with you.
